data.name: Buddhist Mythology
data.description: An enlightened being who delays entry into final nirvana in order to help all sentient beings achieve liberation. The bodhisattva ideal is central to Mahayana Buddhism. Major bodhisattvas include Avalokiteshvara (compassion) and Manjushri (wisdom).

data.name: Buddhist Mythology
data.description: One of the central virtues in Buddhism, the wish for all beings to be free from suffering. Combined with wisdom, compassion is the foundation of the bodhisattva path and is personified by Avalokiteshvara.

data.name: The False God and the True Father in Gnostic Christianity
data.description:
The most revolutionary claim of Gnostic Christianity: the god of the Old Testament - the creator of the material world,
                the lawgiver of Sinai, the jealous deity demanding worship - is not the supreme God. That is
                Yaldabaoth, the Demiurge, the ignorant craftsman born from
                Sophia's defective emanation. Above him, beyond all the archontic spheres,
                dwelling in ineffable light and perfect silence, is the Monad - the true Father revealed by
                Christ. This is the distinction between the god of this world and the
                God of eternity, between the ruler of matter and the source of spirit, between law and grace, judgment and love,
                fear and gnosis. Understanding this difference is the key to spiritual liberation.
relatedConcepts: Gnostic Cosmology - The Monad and the Pleroma
Sabaoth - The Repentant Archon Who Recognized the Father
The Archons - Servants of the Demiurge
Sophia - Divine Wisdom and Mother of the Demiurge
Christ the Redeemer - Revealer of the Unknown Father
Universal Salvation - Even the Demiurge Will Be Redeemed
participants: Perfect Love: "God is love" (1 John 4:8) - no wrath, no violence, no vengeance
Universal Compassion: "Makes his sun rise on the evil and on the good" (Matthew 5:45)
Forgiving: Forgives without sacrifice - "Neither do I condemn you" (John 8:11)
Non-Judgmental: "For God did not send his Son into the world to condemn the world" (John 3:17)
Merciful: "Be merciful, even as your Father is merciful" (Luke 6:36)
Perfect: "Be perfect, as your heavenly Father is perfect" (Matthew 5:48)

significance: Natural Law: Ethics grounded in cosmic order rather than arbitrary divine command
Social Contract: Individual ethics connected to cosmic maintenance
Merit-Based Afterlife: Judgment based on moral worth, not wealth or status
Universal Principles: Truth and justice as absolute standards applying to all
Cosmic Interdependence: Human actions affect divine realm and vice versa
data.name: Egyptian Mythology
relatedConcepts: Dike - Greek goddess of justice and moral order
Dharma - Hindu cosmic law and moral order
Me - Sumerian divine decrees of civilization
The Afterlife - Judgment of the heart

data.name: Greek Mythology
data.description:
The Judgment of Paris
is one of Greek mythology's most consequential tales - a beauty contest among three goddesses that ignited the Trojan War.
When Paris, prince of Troy, was forced to judge who was fairest among Hera,
Athena, and Aphrodite,
his choice set in motion a decade-long war that destroyed civilizations and birthed epic poetry.
relatedConcepts: Hera - Queen of the gods, scorned
Achilles - Son of Thetis and Peleus
participants: Hera - Queen of the gods, scorned

data.name: Japanese Mythology
data.description:
The myth of Amaterasu hiding in the Heavenly Rock Cave
is one of the most celebrated stories in Japanese mythology, recorded in the Kojiki (712 CE) and Nihon Shoki (720 CE).
When Amaterasu,
the sun goddess, sealed herself in a cave to escape her brother Susanoo's
violent rampage, the world plunged into eternal darkness. The myth explains the origins of sacred Shinto rituals, especially kagura dance, and illustrates how cleverness, cooperation, and sacred celebration can overcome even cosmic calamity.

data.name: Japanese Mythology
data.description:
The Creation of Japan
is the foundational myth of Japanese cosmology, recorded in the Kojiki (712 CE) and Nihon Shoki (720 CE).
After the spontaneous generation of the first kami in Takamagahara (the High Plain of Heaven), the divine couple
Izanagi
and Izanami
descended to the primordial ocean and stirred the cosmic waters with a jeweled spear, giving birth to the islands of Japan and the myriad kami that inhabit them.

significance: Forbidden gaze motif - Universal mythic theme
data.name: Japanese Mythology
data.description:
The Journey of Izanagi to Yomi
is one of the foundational myths of Japanese Shinto tradition, recorded in the ancient chronicles Kojiki (712 CE) and Nihon Shoki (720 CE).
After his beloved wife Izanami
dies giving birth to the fire god, Izanagi descends to the underworld realm of
Yomi
to retrieve her. His journey reveals the absolute boundary between life and death‚Äîonce crossed, it cannot be undone without terrible consequences.
relatedConcepts: Orpheus and Eurydice - Greek parallel (failed rescue)
Forbidden gaze motif - Universal mythic theme

data.name: Headed Serpent
data.description:
The myth of Susanoo slaying Yamata-no-Orochi
is one of the most celebrated hero tales in Japanese mythology, recorded in the Kojiki (712 CE) and Nihon Shoki (720 CE).
After being banished from heaven for his violent behavior, the storm god Susanoo
descends to earth where he encounters a family terrorized by an eight-headed, eight-tailed dragon. Through cunning and courage, Susanoo slays the monster, rescues a maiden, and discovers within the dragon's tail the legendary sword Kusanagi-no-Tsurugi - one of the Three Sacred Treasures of Japan. This myth marks Susanoo's transformation from destructive chaos god to heroic protector.

data.name: Sumerian/Babylonian Mythology
data.description:
The Epic of Gilgamesh
is the oldest known work of epic literature, originating in ancient Mesopotamia around 2100 BCE.
It tells the story of Gilgamesh, the mighty king of Uruk,
and his quest for immortality following the death of his beloved companion
Enkidu.
The epic explores timeless themes of friendship, mortality, legacy, and the limits of human ambition,
establishing narrative patterns that would echo through world literature for millennia.
relatedConcepts: Gilgamesh - The hero king of Uruk
Ishtar/Inanna - Goddess of love and war
Enlil - Lord of wind and storm
The Odyssey - Later Greek epic parallel
participants: Gilgamesh - The hero king of Uruk
Ishtar/Inanna - Goddess of love and war
Enlil - Lord of wind and storm

significance: The Underworld (Kur) - Realm of the dead
data.name: Sumerian Mythology
data.description:
The Descent of Inanna
is one of the oldest recorded myths in human history, preserved on cuneiform tablets from ancient Sumer.
The goddess Inanna, Queen of Heaven and Earth, descends to the underworld
realm of Kur
to visit her sister Ereshkigal,
Queen of the Dead. At each of seven gates, she is stripped of her divine powers and regalia,
arriving naked and powerless before the throne of death itself.
relatedConcepts: Inanna - Queen of Heaven and Earth
Enki - God of Wisdom and Water
Sumerian Cosmology - The structure of reality
The Me - Divine powers and laws
The Underworld (Kur) - Realm of the dead
The Underworld - Land of No Return
The Me - Divine powers stripped away
participants: Inanna - Queen of Heaven and Earth
Enki - God of Wisdom and Water
